metadata.title: How to Learn Faster for Data Scientist | by Kurtis Pykes | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Learn Faster for Data Scientist
metadata.description: Going off the back of my story titled “The Reason You’re Frustrated when Trying to Become a Data Scientist”, I had many responses requesting techniques for how we could become better learners. As a…

all_paragraphs: Going off the back of my story titled “The Reason You’re Frustrated when Trying to Become a Data Scientist”, I had many responses requesting techniques for how we could become better learners. As a result of these responses, I got into deep thoughts about what could possibly be meant by a “better learner”?

On that note, I’ve defined a better learner to be someone that retains more knowledge or skills at at a faster rate. This rate varies for different people, however the process of learning is quite similar of which you can learn more about in the link below.

The familiar saying of “With great power comes great responsibility” does not quite capture the fact that we yield extreme power within us. However, when we flip this saying on its head it states that power can be found when we have taken responsibility. Great responsibility for what you ask? What we focus on, the meaning of things, our mistakes, our accountability. Our present results are a manifestation of our past decisions and to ensure we achieve our desired results in the future we ought to take responsibility of the present moment.
“With great responsibility comes great power” — Jim Kwik
If you want to be a better learner, think FAST.

Babies are super learners! I’ve been fortunate enough to have my 1 year old niece (as of writing) that I can observe, so there is no need for a thought experiment. I’ve seen her go from being carried everywhere, to crawling, to standing, to static dancing, to walking, to dynamic dancing, to climbing stairs, to opening doors and now speaking 3 words — “disgusting”, “yucky”, and “uh-oh”. Hence, much of my examples may be in relation to my observation of my niece. Nevertheless, this will not stop us from doing a simple form of transfer learning to apply these examples to Data Science.
There are 3 things that we ought to forget for us to become better learners, and for those of us that are married in our community… No, your Wife is not one of them. In no particular order:

When we are young we are total sponges. The earth is our science lab. Let’s imagine if my niece had it lodged in her psyche that she already knew how to walk the moment she was born — some disaster that would be. Her bones would instantly fail her because she quite simply does not have the facilities for that.
Yet, this is what we do! When we feel as though we already know something, it’s easier to gloss over that information when we review it. To become a better learn, we must forget what we already know.
How much faster would I of understood a inner-workings of a deep neural network if I took the time to get to grips with Linear Regression and Logistic Regression.
“Your mind is like a parachute; It only works when it’s open”
#2 - What is not Urgent
I dare you to speak to my niece whilst she is watching Mr Tumble on CBeebies. You would be voraciously ignored. Hence why I don’t mess with here when Mr Tumble is on, bad idea.

I know there are few people in this world that believe they can multitask, and you know what, they probably can. Unfortunately, I am apart of the significantly larger portion of people that is not so lucky in this department. But, if you are in this group of people note that this is not our flaw, it is our power. When we are thinking about multiple things our mind is literally all over the place, flicking attention between task. Alternatively, when we focus on one task and forget all others we enter into an extremely delicate place called the present.
If you remember from the prelude, it is what we do in this place that will determine the results we achieve in the future.
“When we forget what is not urgent, we provide ourselves with an opportunity to achieve better results in the future by entering the present.” — Kurtis Pykes ;)
My niece fell over after her first two steps and not for one minute did I think she thought walking is not for her because she stood straight up and tried again.
Here are some limiting beliefs I’ve heard from beginning Data Scientist — feel free to add your own if you’ve heard some interesting ones:
These statements may be facts, however it is not true that these reasons are what is stopping you from becoming a Data Scientist — it is your beliefs.
“If you fight for your limitations, you get to keep them” — Jim Kwik

I wouldn’t call myself an academic. Infact, by choice I went to college 4 years late and though it was two days a week for 12 months, I couldn’t wait for it to be over — it’s understandable though, I was studying accounting.

I am not to sure about other countries, nevertheless, I am completely against how we are taught to learn in the UK — or maybe it was just my school, I don’t know. The impression that good learning is consuming information quietly has and will always absurd to me, maybe it works for others but for me, it’s a no no.
“Learning is not a spectator Sport” — Jim Kwik

We humans are creators, that’s where our deepest learning lays its head. To further extend on this, when we are active in the process of creation we can absolutely learn whatever it is we want. How can you become more active in your learning you ask?
“The more active you are, the more you will learn”

Personal experiences as well as extensive psychological research that was carried out by Johns Hopkins Medical Institution confirms that events that occur during heightened states of emotion are much more memorable than less dramatic occurrences. The research states that “a hormone released during emotional arousal ‘primes’ nerve cells to remember events by increasing their chemical sensitivity at sites where nerves rewire to form new memory circuits.”
Information x Emotion = Long Term Memory

For many, this is an “ah ha” moment. Yes, you forgot everything that was taught to you at school because you was probably in a bored state in the classroom. By changing the state we are in we can become much better learners.
How Can I improve my state?
“Sell your cleverness and buy bewilderment.”– Jalaluddin Rumi, 13th Century Sufi Mysti
“If you want cut your learning curve in half, learn with the intention of teaching it to somebody else.” — Unknown

Teaching really does give you some crazy boost. I remember when someone first approached me about one of my articles and was asking me a question about a project they were working on… We don’t want to misguide people, so naturally we’d pay more extra piece of attention, we’d take better notes, we’d do anything we regard as necessary in order to provide sound information. Furthermore, when you are teaching and trip up on a certain phenomena, this serves as feedback for what you need to learn deeper to get a better understanding.
“When I teach something, I get to learn it twice.” — Jim Kwik

I often say to people that they should blog about what they are learning, or find some way to make what they are doing public so that others may learn. That extra care and feedback is vital for your growth, as it has been and will continue to be for me.

Becoming better learners is a skill, and like any skill, it will take time to full birth itself. Nonetheless, constant deliberate practice will enhance your ability to learn in return increasing the probability of you fulfilling your goal of becoming a Data Scientist.
Note: This story is highly inspired by the teachings of Jim Kwik. He has an extremely useful Podcast called “Kwik Brain” and I suggest you check it out here.
If there is anything that you think I have missed, something that you’d like to point out to me, or if you are still unsure about something, your feedback is valuable. Send a response!
However, If you’d like to get in contact with me, I am most active on LinkedIn and I’d love to connect with you also.

I recently added to my PyTrix series, where I present cool things that can be done in Python that are useful for Data Scientist. I’ve updated my schedule and will now be doing this series on a weekly basis. You can see the first two PyTrix stories in the links below:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
